introduction.p: Here, we want to address the question: How do you get net electric field if multiple fields are acting at the same time?

Recall that net force on an object is a vector sum of the forces on that object. Now, if several charges act on a test charge Q, with forces \vec F_1, \vec F_2, \cdots, \vec F_N, then, net electric force on Q will be
\vec F_e = \vec F_1 + \vec F_2 + \cdots + \vec F_N.
Now, if we divide both sides by the test charge, we will get
\frac{\vec F_e}{Q} = \frac{\vec F_1}{Q} + \frac{\vec F_2}{Q} + \cdots + \frac{\vec F_N}{Q}.
Each of the \vec F_i/Q is actually, the electric field from the corresponding source, which we can denote by \vec E_i. One the left is the net electric force divided by the test charge, so, we get the net electric field there, which we denote by \vec E_P. Therefore, we find that, just like forces, electric fields also add vectorially to give the net electric field.
\vec E_P = \vec E_1 + \vec E_2 + \cdots + \vec E_N.
This result is called superposition of electric fields. We will work out examples of this principle below.

exercise.title: Superposition of Electric Field of Four Charged Plates

sidebyside.p: Four charged plates are arranged with positive plates facing the negative plates. The charges on the opposing plates along horizontal direction produce an electric field of magnitude E_1 = 3 \text{ N/C} in the horizontal direction as shown in the figure, and the other two plates produce E_2 = 4 \text{ N/C} in the vertical direction. What is the electric field of all charges?

answer.p: 5\text{ N/C} at 53^{\circ} counterclockwise from the horizontal field direction.

solution.p:
We need to add the electric fields vectorially. Since the fields are already in the perpendicular directions, it is easy to work out the magnitude by Pythagora's theorem.
E = \sqrt{ 3^2 + 4^2} = 5\text{ N/C}.

sidebyside.p:
The direction can be given by the counterclockwise angle with respect to the horizontal direction,
\theta = \tan^{-1}\left( \dfrac{4}{3} \right) = 53^{\circ}.

exercise.title: Electric Field of Two Charges at a Point on Line Joining the Charges

statement.p: Find the electric field at the origin.

hint.p: The electric field of the two charges are in the opposite direction.

answer.p: 9\text{ N/C} in the positive x direction.

solution.p: The following figure shows the electric field of the two charges at the origin are along the x axis, but they are in the opposite direction. We will compute x components of the two fields so that we can deal with their addition through the sign of the components.

The x component of the fields are
E_{1x} \amp = + k\dfrac{|q_1|}{r_1^2} = 9\times 10^{9} \times \dfrac{5\times 10^9}{2^2} = 11.25\text{ N/C}, E_{2x} \amp = - k\dfrac{|q_2|}{r_2^2} = -9\times 10^{9} \times \dfrac{4\times 10^9}{4^2} = -2.25\text{ N/C}.
Therefore, x component of the net electric field at origin is
E_x = E_{1x} + E_{2x} = 11.25 + (- 2.25) = 9\text{ N/C}.
This is the only non-zero component of the field. Therefore, electric field at origin has magnitude 9\text{ N/C} and direction in the positive x direction.

exercise.title: Electric Field of Two Charges at a Point Perpendicular to Line Joining the Charges

statement.p: Find the magnitude and direction of the electric field at point P.

hint.p: Work with x and y components of electric fields from each charge.

answer.p: 7.52\text{ N/C} counterclockwise at 37^\circ from the positive x axis.

solution.p: The following figure shows the electric field of the two charges are pointed in xy-plane. We will compute x and y components of the two fields so that we can deal with their addition through their components.

The x and y components of electric field \vec E_1 are
E_{1x} \amp = k\dfrac{q_1}{r_1^2} \dfrac{x_P-x_1}{r_1}, E_{1y} \amp = k\dfrac{q_2}{r_2^2} \dfrac{y_P-y_1}{r_1},
and similarly for charge q_2. Computing the numerical values is easier by working out the parts of the formula first.
r_1 \amp = \sqrt{ \left(x_P-x_1 \right)^2 + \left(y_P-y_1 \right)^2 } \amp = \sqrt{ \left(0-(-2) \right)^2 + \left(1-0 \right)^2 } = \sqrt{ 5}\text{ m}. r_2 \amp = \sqrt{ \left(x_P-x_2 \right)^2 + \left(y_P-y_2 \right)^2 } \amp = \sqrt{ \left(0-(4) \right)^2 + \left(1-0 \right)^2 } = \sqrt{ 17}\text{ m}.
Therefore, the components of \vec E_1 will be
E_{1x} \amp = 9\times 10^9\times\dfrac{5\times 10^{-9}}{ (\sqrt{5})^2 } \times \dfrac{0-(-2)}{\sqrt{5}} = 8.05\text{ N/C}, E_{1y} \amp = 9\times 10^9\times\dfrac{5\times 10^{-9}}{ (\sqrt{5})^2 } \times \dfrac{1-0}{\sqrt{5}} = 4.02\text{ N/C},
and those of \vec E_2 will be
E_{2x} \amp = 9\times 10^9\times\dfrac{4\times 10^{-9}}{ (\sqrt{17})^2 } \times \dfrac{0-(4)}{\sqrt{17}} = -2.05\text{ N/C}, E_{2y} \amp = 9\times 10^9\times\dfrac{4\times 10^{-9}}{ (\sqrt{17})^2 } \times \dfrac{1-0}{\sqrt{17}} = 0.51\text{ N/C},
Therefore, the net electric field at P has the following components.
E_x\amp = E_{1x} + E_{2x} = 8.05-2.05 = 6.00\text{ N/C}, E_y\amp = E_{1y} + E_{2y} = 4.02+0.51 = 4.53\text{ N/C},
The magnitude of electric field will be
E_P = \sqrt{ 6.00^2 + 4.53^2 } = 7.52\text{ N/C},
and the direction will be given by the counterclockwise angle \theta from the positive x axis,
\theta = \tan^{-1}\left(\dfrac{4.53}{6.00} \right) = 37^\circ.

exercise.title: Electric Field at the Center of Square from Different Charges at the Corners

statement.p: Four charges A( +3\text{ nC} ), B( -4\text{ nC} ), C( +6\text{ nC} ) and D( -9\text{ nC} ) are fixed to the successive corners of a square of side 5\ \mu\text{m}.

hint.p: Place A, B, C, and D on the axes and the center at the origin. Vectorially, add up the electric fields of the four charges.

answer.p: Magnitude = 4.19\times 10^{12}\text {N/C}, Direction: 31^\circ clockwise below B-to-D direction.

solution.p: First decision we make is how to place the charges so that our calculaiton is simplest. I found that if I place the charges on x and y coordinates with the center at the origin, the calculation works out quite simple.

The magnitude if the electric field will be
E= \sqrt{ 3.59^3 + 2.16^2 } \times 10^{12} = 4.19\times 10^{12}\text{ N/C}.
Since point (-3.59, 2.16) is in the second quadrant, the direction will be clockwise from the negative xaxis
\theta = \tan^{-1} \left( \dfrac{2.16}{-3.59}\right) = -31^{\circ}.
